definitions: of, from, or relating to Egypt, its people, culture, or language
relating to or characteristic of ancient Egyptian civilization, art, or culture
examples: The Egyptian government announced new economic reforms
Egyptian cotton is famous for its superior quality
The museum features Egyptian artifacts from ancient dynasties
Egyptian hieroglyphics covered the ancient temple walls

definitions: of, relating to, or characteristic of the reign of Queen Elizabeth I of England
characteristic of the literature, drama, or culture during Elizabeth I's reign
examples: The Elizabethan era witnessed remarkable cultural achievements
Elizabethan England experienced significant economic growth
Shakespeare wrote his plays during the Elizabethan period
The theater features authentic Elizabethan stage design

definitions: of, from, or relating to England, its people, or their culture
of or relating to the English language in any of its varieties
examples: English weather is notoriously unpredictable throughout the year
The English countryside offers beautiful scenic views
She teaches English grammar to international students
English vocabulary has borrowed words from many languages

definitions: united or joined together by treaty, agreement, or common purpose
connected by nature, qualities, or having similar characteristics or purposes
examples: Allied forces launched a coordinated military campaign
The allied nations signed a comprehensive trade agreement
Mathematics and physics are closely allied subjects
Their interests were allied with corporate objectives

definitions: of, relating to, or found in high mountain areas, especially the Alps
characteristic of or adapted to the environmental conditions of high mountains
examples: Alpine meadows bloom with wildflowers in summer
The alpine climate requires special survival adaptations
Alpine skiing requires different techniques than cross-country
Alpine plants have adapted to harsh conditions

definitions: of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true or genuine
well-known but probably untrue or invented; of questionable truth or accuracy
examples: The apocryphal story has been repeated for generations
Many apocryphal tales surround the famous author's life
His apocryphal claim about meeting celebrities fooled nobody
The article contained several apocryphal statistics

definitions: fastened or stuck together with glue or another adhesive substance
giving complete attention to something; unable to stop watching or listening
examples: The broken vase was carefully glued back together
The poster remained glued to the wall for years
Her eyes were glued to the television screen
The children sat glued to their seats during the performance

definitions: having a sticky, glue-like consistency; viscous and adhesive in texture
examples: Glutinous rice becomes sticky when cooked properly
The glutinous substance made handling difficult
The glutinous texture of the syrup coated everything
Glutinous wheat flour creates a chewy texture

definitions: provoked or urged to action through persistent annoyance or criticism
examples: The goaded bull charged at the matador
She felt goaded by their constant criticism
He was goaded into making a hasty decision
The goaded crowd finally erupted in protest

definitions: in sports, having no goals scored; ending without any goals
lacking clear aims, objectives, or direction in life or activities
examples: The match ended in a goalless draw
They played ninety minutes of goalless football
He felt goalless after graduating from university
Her goalless wandering reflected her current confusion

definitions: used to express anger, frustration, or to add strong emphasis to something
examples: That goddamn car won't start again this morning
He's a goddamn genius at solving problems
The goddamn weather ruined our outdoor plans
This goddamn traffic is making us late

definitions: not recognizing or believing in any god or divine power
characterized by wickedness, immorality, or lack of religious principles
examples: The godless society rejected all religious institutions
His godless philosophy challenged traditional beliefs
Their godless behavior shocked the conservative community
The novel depicted a godless wasteland

definitions: having qualities or powers that seem to belong to a god or deity
examples: The athlete displayed godlike strength and endurance
His godlike powers amazed the ancient people
She moved with godlike grace across the stage
The emperor demanded godlike worship from subjects

definitions: devout in religious belief and practice; showing reverence for God
conforming to the laws or will of God; morally excellent and virtuous
examples: The godly woman attended church services daily
He led a godly life devoted to prayer
Their godly conduct earned community respect
The godly principles guided all their decisions

definitions: currently taking place, in progress, or continuing to happen
existing, available, or in operation at the present time
examples: The going rate for babysitters has increased
This is a going concern with steady profits
Check the going prices before making an offer
The business remains a going enterprise

definitions: made of or containing the precious yellow metallic element gold
having the color of gold; bright yellow or yellow-brown in color
examples: She wore a beautiful gold necklace
The gold coins were worth a fortune
The gold sunset painted the sky beautifully
Her gold dress shimmered under the lights

definitions: having the color of gold; bright yellow or yellowish-brown
of superior quality or value; excellent, precious, or advantageous
marked by prosperity, happiness, and achievement; highly favorable
examples: The golden wheat fields stretched for miles
Her golden hair shone in the sunlight
This is a golden opportunity for advancement
He has a golden voice perfect for radio
They remembered the golden days of youth
The company entered its golden age of growth

definitions: no longer present; having left or disappeared from a place
completely used up, finished, or no longer available
having died or passed away; no longer alive or existing
examples: The cookies are all gone from the jar
She's gone to the store for groceries
Our savings are completely gone after the repairs
The opportunity is gone forever now
My grandfather has been gone for ten years
Those traditions are long gone now

definitions: silly, foolish, or mildly stupid in an amusing way
playfully silly or eccentric in a harmless, endearing manner
examples: His goofy smile always made everyone laugh
Stop making those goofy faces during class
She has a goofy sense of humor we love
The goofy character became the show's favorite

definitions: extremely beautiful, attractive, or magnificent in appearance
very pleasant, enjoyable, or delightful; wonderful in quality
examples: She looked absolutely gorgeous in her wedding dress
The gorgeous sunset took our breath away
We had gorgeous weather for the picnic
That's a gorgeous piece of music

definitions: involving or showing much bloodshed, violence, or killing
involving unpleasant details, especially about violence or injury
examples: The gory battle scene was too intense
Horror movies often feature gory special effects
He spared us the gory details of the accident
The news report included gory descriptions

definitions: extremely light, delicate, and translucent like a spider's web
so thin and light as to be almost transparent or insubstantial
examples: The gossamer fabric floated in the breeze
Gossamer threads of spider silk caught the dew
Her gossamer wings sparkled in the moonlight
The gossamer veil barely concealed her face

definitions: relating to a style of architecture common in western Europe from 12th-16th centuries
characterized by gloom, mystery, and the supernatural; dark and atmospheric
examples: The gothic cathedral featured pointed arches and spires
Gothic architecture dominated medieval European cities
She writes gothic novels about haunted mansions
The gothic atmosphere of the film was compelling

definitions: having the power or authority to control and direct; ruling
serving to control, determine, or strongly influence something
examples: The governing body made important policy decisions
The governing party won the recent election
The governing principle behind our decision was fairness
Governing factors include cost and availability

definitions: of, relating to, or concerning the government or its functions and activities
examples: Governmental agencies oversee public safety regulations
The governmental response to the crisis was swift
Governmental policies affect millions of citizens daily
She works in a governmental department

definitions: moving in a smooth, elegant way that appears natural and effortless
showing grace, tact, or appropriateness in manner or behavior
examples: The dancer's graceful movements captivated the audience
Swans are known for their graceful swimming
She made a graceful exit from the awkward situation
His graceful acceptance of defeat impressed everyone

definitions: courteous, kind, and pleasant in manner, especially to those of lower status
showing elegant generosity and good taste in behavior or lifestyle
showing divine grace; merciful, compassionate, or forgiving
examples: The gracious host made everyone feel welcome
She was gracious even when receiving criticism
They live in a gracious mansion with beautiful gardens
The gracious living of a bygone era
By God's gracious mercy, they survived the disaster
The king showed gracious forgiveness to rebels

definitions: arranged in grades, ranks, or levels according to size, quality, or intensity
changing gradually from one level, shade, or degree to another
examples: The graded exercises increase in difficulty progressively
Students complete graded assignments throughout the semester
The graded color scheme transitions from light to dark
A graded slope makes climbing easier

definitions: happening or changing slowly over a long period of time
proceeding or advancing by small, steady degrees or stages
examples: The gradual increase in temperature went unnoticed
Her gradual recovery took several months
We made gradual progress toward our goal
The gradual slope was easy to climb

definitions: of, relating to, or for university graduates or graduation
relating to or engaged in studies beyond the first or bachelor's degree
examples: She attended the graduate ceremony with her family
Graduate employment rates have improved this year
He's enrolled in graduate school for his master's
Graduate courses require more independent research

definitions: marked with regular intervals or degrees for measuring
arranged in a series of stages, levels, or degrees of intensity
examples: Use a graduated cylinder for accurate measurements
The graduated scale shows precise temperature readings
The graduated tax system charges higher earners more
They introduced graduated penalties for repeat offenses

definitions: having a texture with visible grains or granular particles
having a rough, granular texture; not smooth or fine
examples: The grainy photograph was taken with old film
The grainy texture of whole wheat bread
The video quality was grainy in low light
The grainy sand stuck to our feet

definitions: of or relating to grammar or the study of language structure
conforming to the rules of grammar; correctly formed according to grammar
examples: She teaches grammatical concepts to language learners
The grammatical structure of English differs from Chinese
That sentence is perfectly grammatical despite sounding odd
Check for grammatical errors before submitting

definitions: magnificent and imposing in appearance, size, or style; impressive
of the highest rank or importance; principal or chief
including everything or everyone; complete and comprehensive in scope
examples: The grand ballroom could accommodate five hundred guests
They made a grand entrance at the gala
She won the grand prize in the competition
The grand finale featured spectacular fireworks
The grand total came to ten thousand dollars
His grand plan involved restructuring everything

definitions: impressive or magnificent in appearance or style, especially pretentiously so
excessively grand or ambitious; unrealistically elaborate or extravagant
examples: The palace had a grandiose architectural design
His grandiose mansion impressed all visitors
Her grandiose plans never came to fruition
He made grandiose claims about his achievements

definitions: given, allowed, or admitted as a privilege or right
accepted or assumed as true without question or proof
examples: Permission was granted to build the extension
She was granted access to confidential files
Granted that mistakes were made, we can improve
Taking our freedoms for granted is dangerous

definitions: consisting of or appearing to consist of small grains or particles
characterized by a high level of detail or specificity
examples: The granular texture of sand between your fingers
Sugar has a granular consistency
We need more granular data for accurate analysis
The report provides granular insights into spending

definitions: processed into small grains or granules; having a granular form
examples: Add two cups of granulated sugar to the mixture
The granulated fertilizer spreads easily
Granulated garlic is convenient for cooking
The medicine comes in granulated form

definitions: showing or describing something in very clear, powerful, and detailed way
relating to visual art, especially involving drawing, engraving, or lettering
giving a clear and effective picture through detailed description
examples: The movie contains graphic violence and gore
The graphic images disturbed many viewers
She studied graphic design at art school
His graphic novels have won several awards
He gave a graphic account of the accident
The book contains graphic descriptions of poverty

definitions: relating to or using graphs, charts, or other visual representations
relating to computer graphics or visual display on computers
examples: The graphical representation made the data clearer
Use graphical methods to solve the equation
The graphical user interface is intuitive
Modern games require powerful graphical processors

definitions: greedily eager to obtain money, power, or material possessions
examples: His grasping nature alienated potential business partners
The grasping landlord raised rents excessively
She had a grasping attitude toward inheritance
The novel depicts grasping merchants exploiting workers

definitions: originating from or supported by ordinary people rather than leaders or elite
examples: The grassroots movement gained national attention quickly
Grassroots support helped win the election
The grassroots campaign relied on small donations
This grassroots organization serves local communities

definitions: covered with or containing grass; having much grass growing
having the characteristics or appearance of grass
examples: The grassy meadow stretched to the horizon
Children played on the grassy hillside
The wine had a grassy, herbaceous flavor
The grassy smell of fresh hay filled the barn

definitions: feeling or showing appreciation and thanks for something received or done
expressing or conveying gratitude and appreciation warmly and readily
examples: I'm grateful for your help during difficult times
She felt grateful to have such supportive friends
He sent a grateful letter to his mentor
Their grateful response touched our hearts

definitions: giving pleasure or satisfaction; pleasing and rewarding
examples: Teaching can be an extremely gratifying career
It's gratifying to see our efforts succeed
The gratifying response exceeded all expectations
She found the work deeply gratifying

definitions: sounding harsh, rough, and unpleasant; irritating to hear
producing a harsh rubbing or scraping sound
examples: Her grating voice annoyed everyone in the office
The grating noise kept us awake all night
The grating sound of metal on concrete hurt our ears
Chalk makes a grating sound on the blackboard

definitions: given or done without charge or payment; free of cost
examples: The hotel provides gratis breakfast for all guests
Admission to the museum is gratis on Sundays
They offered gratis consultations for new clients
The software is available gratis for students

definitions: done without good reason; unnecessary and often harmful or offensive
given or done free of charge; not involving payment
examples: The movie contained gratuitous violence throughout
His gratuitous comments offended many people
The lawyer provided gratuitous legal advice
They received gratuitous assistance from volunteers

definitions: giving cause for alarm or concern; seriously bad or dangerous
serious, solemn, and dignified in manner or appearance
examples: The patient's condition is grave but stable
They face grave danger if they continue
He spoke in a grave tone about the situation
Her grave expression showed deep concern

definitions: containing, covered with, or consisting of gravel
having a rough, harsh quality, especially of voice
examples: The gravelly path crunched under their feet
They walked along the gravelly beach
His gravelly voice betrayed years of smoking
The singer's gravelly tone suited blues music
